Sequence Information.Peptide Name: Parasin I (Lys-rich; natural AMPs; fish, animals; histone-derived; SeqAR; truncation Derivative; BBMms; UCLL1)
Sequence Information.Source: skin mucosa, catfish,Parasilurus asotus; Also detected in the skin mucus of wounded eel, loach, and rainbow trout
Sequence Information.Crucial residues: The N-terminal Lys is essential for membrane-binding activity of the peptide. The last four residues can be deleted.

Literature Information.Literature: Discovery: N-terminal fragment of Histone H2A, produced by cathepsin D in the skin mucus. Only the mucus extracts from wounded catfish (not normal unwounded) had parasin I.Structure:  In SDS micelles, residues 9-17 are helical (Peptides 2008; 29: 1102-1108).Activity: Active against fish-specific pathogens A. salmonicida, C. aquatilis, Y. ruckeri, E. ictaluri, and L. garvieae (MIC 5-15 ug/ml).MOA:bacteria: membrane targeting.Found in multiple species.Updated 4/2009; 7/2021; 11/2023 GW.
Literature Information.Author: Park IY, Park CB, Kim MS, Kim SC1998
Literature Information.Title: Parasin I, an antimicrobial peptide derived from histon H2A in the catfish, Parasilurus asotus
